awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a 400 MHz NMR Spectrometer for Research and Education
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation and the Chemistry Research Instrumentation programs. Northern Illinois University is acquiring a 400 MHz nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectrometer to support research of Professor Evgueni Nesterov and colleagues Narayan Hosmane, Ralph Wheeler, Douglas Klumpp and Timothy Hagen. This spectrometer allows research in a variety of fields such as those that accelerate chemical reactions of significant economic importance, as well as permitting study of chemically and biologically relevant species. In general, Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectroscopy is one of the most powerful tools available to chemists for the elucidation of the structure of molecules. It is used to identify unknown substances, to characterize specific arrangements of atoms within molecules, and to study the dynamics of interactions between molecules in solution or in the solid state. Access to state-of-the-art NMR spectrometers is essential to chemists who are carrying out frontier research. This instrument is an integral part of teaching as well as research and research training of undergraduate and graduate students in chemistry and biochemistry at this institution as well as collaborators from regional primarily undergraduate institutions.

The award of the NMR spectrometer is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels. It especially impacts studies developing synthetic organic methodology and transition metal and super-acid catalyzed reactions. The instrumentation is also used for fundamental studies in organic photochemistry and the design and study of small-molecule ligands for protein binding. In addition, it allows the development of an analytical platform for fluorescent screening of enzyme inhibitors and studies on the methods of controlled preparation of semiconducting polymer materials and advanced dual-function organic light-emitting diode (OLED) compounds.  The instrument also serves researchers developing environmentally friendly industrially relevant catalytic processes and reactions and those designing oligonucleotide-based molecular switches. The NMR spectrometer is employed in the characterization of synthesized boron-carbon cage compounds which are used in neutron-capture therapy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This grant funded the acquisition and installation of a new advanced 500 MHz NMR spectrometer at the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry at Northern Illinois University (NIU). Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectrometry is the most critical characterization and molecular structure analysis tool for a broad range of research fields in chemistry, biochemistry, molecular biology, materials science, etc. The new spectrometer has significantly enhanced research capabilities at NIU having affected progress of a large number of research projects that critically depend on the availability of a modern NMR instrumentation. The research programs that especially benefitted from the new NMR spectrometer encompass a wide range of topics, including development of synthetic organic methodology for medicinal chemistry and pharmaceutical development, catalytic organic reactions for chemical industry, fundamental studies in organic photochemistry, developing a high throughput platform for fluorescent screening of enzyme inhibitors in cancer research, studies on new methods of controlled preparation of semiconducting polymer materials for sensing and light-emitting applications, engineering hybrid materials for high-performance perovskite solar cells, research in new electrolytes for Li ion batteries, etc. The majority of this research is sponsored by federal funding agencies, and the success of these research programs to ensure the continuing growth of NIU as a research-intensive educational institution hinges on the availability of a modern and reliable NMR instrumentation. The acquisition of the advanced NMR instrument also enhanced the ongoing and future training activities that foster synergy between research and education, and have a profound effect on educational capabilities both at NIU and of our regional community colleges and PUIs partners. With the increasing diversity of the NIU students, the acquisition enabled mitigating a growing demand for research and instructional instrument time, and enhanced the students experience at NIU while improving their training and quality of education, eventually allowing them to successfully enter the national workforce in the advanced areas of science and technology. In addition, advancing the NMR capabilities enabled expanding the number of teaching experiments utilizing NMR spectrometry, as well as incorporating NMR technique in additional laboratory classes for NIU science and engineering students. With established NIU partnerships and growing outreach to regional colleges, the new spectrometer has impacted even a larger number of science and Chemistry students in the northern Illinois area.
